  ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Conquest of Minas Ithil-Sige of Osgiliath- Defense of Minas Anor of Osgiliath - Second Siege of Minas Ithil -Battle of Dagorlad - Siege of Barad-dûr

SIEGE OF OSGILIATH was a battle between the hosts of Mordor a Gondor
during the War of the Last Alliance at Second Age.


Prelude

Soon after conquest of Minas Ithil the Witch-king of Angmar took control
of the fort, having collected a huge army of Orcs and Evil Men he
prepared to attack Osgiliath


Background

When the Witch King fell on Osgiliath, Isildur as best he could be
organized and prepared a desperate defense, reflecting catapults Isildur
did pay dearly for the crossing of Anduin to the forces of Mordor, but
could not hold the Legions of Mordor and forced to retire. The main
contingent attacked Osgiliath East, while two other contingent the river
to the north and south and attack Osgiliath West.

Isildur had to leave Osgiliath East to defend the West but when he cross
the river saw could not contain both armies, so he run to Minas Anor as
quicker possible to prepare for the attack.

title: Mirkwood warriors
text:
MIRKWOOD WARRIORS are warriors of the Woodland Realm.


History

In TA 2941, they participated in the Battle of the Five Armies. They are
similar to the Galadhrim warriors and the Ñoldor Warriors, but they
apparently have more variants in armour, for example, Thranduil's guards
are silver, but the regular troops are golden, another type of warrior
that can be considered a variant of these are the palace guards of
Mirkwood, they mount guard over the Elven king's halls.

They wear more protective armour than the Galadhrim, but in comparison
to the Ñoldor, they have the same protection, if not less, making them
sturdy warriors that can cut through Goblin ranks with ease.

Quotes

GANDALF: My lord, dispatch this force to Ravenhill. Thorin must be
warned! THRANDUIL: By all means, warn him. I have spent enough Elvish
blood in defense of this accursed land. No more!

title: Vorotemnar
text:
VOROTEMNAR were great manacles made to hold Melko (Melkor) in the
earlier forms of the legendarium.

They combined with the chain Angaino and Ilterindi, the fetters were to
hold Melko indefinitely.


History

Vorotemnar were made by the Vala Aulë out of the metal Tilkal and were
said to bind forever. When Tulkas had finally subdued Melko, Aulë set
both wrists in the manacles.

title: Ilterindi
text:
ILTERINDI were the great fetters made to hold Melko (Melkor) in the
earlier forms of the legendarium.

They combined with the chain Angaino and Vorotemnar, the manacles were
to hold Melko indefinitely.


History

Ilterindi were made by the Vala Aulë out of the metal Tilkal. When
Tulkas had finally subdued Melko, Aulë set the Ilterindi on each of his
ankles.

title: Orc Berserker
text:
ORC BERSERKERS were the most ruthless and fearsome Orcs of Gundabad.
Their chieftain is Bolg, spawn of Azog.

title: Korin
text:
“KORIN” refers to a large circular hedge that surrounded large swards in
the earlier forms of Tolkien's legendarium.

The surrounding materials could be made of stone, thorny bushes, or even
trees of all kinds. The Elf-queen Meril-i-Turinqi of Tol Eressëa
lived in a house within a Korin of Elm trees.

title: Oiomurë
text:
OIOMURË was the dim land between the shores of Araman and the mountains
of Pelóri, high in the North near Helcaraxë at the Westshores
of Belegaer. At the western side of that frozen place were long and
dreary plains, but bleak and ever colder as the ice drew nearer, and it
was filled with mists.


History

After the Darkening of Valinor, Morgoth and Ungoliant fled the pursuing
Valar northwards through the barren and cold land of Araman, traversing
Oiomúrë and the Helcaraxë in order to reach Middle-earth.

The Ñoldor led by Fingolfin during their Flight possibly as well passed
through Oiomúrë on their march to Beleriand from Valinor through the
Helcaraxë.

title: Skirmish in Cirith Ungol
text:
The SKIRMISH IN CIRITH UNGOL was a small conflict between Gorbag's and
Shagrat's forces during the War of the Ring, albeit a very important
one, as it allowed Frodo and Sam to escape from Cirith Ungol and
continue their quest to destroy the One Ring.


History

After Frodo's unconscious body was brought to Cirith Ungol by Orcs for
torturing and questioning, Gorbag and Shagrat began looting him. After
finding his Mithril Vest, Gorbag wanted to keep it for himself, but
Shagrat insisted that it be given to the Great Eye, most likely out of
fear than loyalty. This lead to a skirmish between the Uruks and Orcs in
the tower, leaving almost every one of them dead. Moments later, Sam
sneaked into the tower, killed a few of the remiaiing Uruks, and saw
Gorbag's failed killing attempt. He then rescued Frodo and they both
escaped to continue their quest to Mount Doom.

title: Morgul Attack Troll
text:
The MORGUL ATTACK TROLL was a breed of Olog-hai and unlike the Mordor
breed, these Lack size, strength and armor. During the Siege of Minas
Tirith, these were the first troops to attack the insides of the city
once the wolfs head Grond had smashed the door open. Some of them had a
little armor, but not as much as the Mordor breed.


Statistics

These trolls weren't at all as strong as the ones at the black gate and
were very weak to incoming arrows and spears. They cannot be mistaken
with the Mountain-trolls who are nearby during the same siege.


See Also

-   Mordor Attack Troll
-   Olog-hai

title: House of Tulkas
text:
The HOUSE OF TULKAS was the dwelling of Tulkas in Valmar, the city of
the Valar in Valinor.


History

The house is said to have sprung “_high into the air with many
storeys_”, and to sport a “_tower of bronze and pillars of copper in a
wide arcade_”. Tulkas's house also had a court, where champions engaged
in athletic games. There would often Nessa, wife of Tulkas, appear to
bring goblets of wine and drinks to the players. 


Notes

-   The house could have been referenced by the Greek God of war Ares.

title: Mounds of the Kings of Rohan
text:
The MOUNDS OF THE KINGS OF ROHAN was where the Kings of Rohan were
buried.


History

The Mounds were located in Edoras somewhere probably near the Meduseld.
The Mounds consisted of two lines. The first line was where the first
nine kings were buried with Helm in the ninth and final one of that
line. After the death of Fréaláf Hildeson, a new line of Mounds was
begun were which all the kings afterwards were laid to rest.

title: Bridge of Tavrobel
text:
The BRIDGE OF TAVROBEL was a bridge in or near the town of Tavrobel on
the island of Tol Eressëa.


History

The Bridge of Tavrobel was grey bridge that went over the two rivers
Afros and Gruir. The Gnome-folk lived near or around it.

title: Lament for Boromir
text:
The LAMENT FOR BOROMIR was sung by Aragorn II and Legolas during the
funeral of Boromir.

Aragorn sang: Through Rohan over fen and field where the long grass
grows The West Wind comes walking, and about the walls it goes. ‘What
news from the West, O wandering wind, do you bring to me tonight? Have
you seen Boromir the Tall by moon or by starlight? ‘I saw him ride over
seven streams, over waters wide and grey, I saw him walk in empty lands
until he passed away Into the shadows of the North, I saw him then no
more. The North Wind may have heard the horn of the son of Denethor, ‘O
Boromir! From the high walls westward I looked afar, But you came not
from the empty lands where no men are.’

Then Legolas sang: From the mouths of the Sea the South Wind flies, from
the sandhills and the stones, The wailing of the gulls it bears, and at
the gate it moans. ‘What news from the South, O sighing wind, do you
bring to me at eve? Where now is Boromir the Fair? He tarries and I
grieve. ‘Ask not of me where he doth dwell – so many bones there lie, On
the white shores and the dark shores under the stormy sky, So many have
passed down Anduin to find the flowing Sea. Ask of the North Wind news
of them the North Wind sends to me!’ ‘O Boromir! Beyond the gate the
seaward roads runs south, But you came not with the wailing gulls from
the grey sea’s mouth’.

Then Aragorn sang again: From the Gate of the Kings the North Wind
rides, and past the roaring falls, And clear and cold about the tower
its loud horn calls. ‘What news from the North, O mighty wind, do you
bring to me today? What news of Boromir the bold? For he is long away.’
‘Beneath Amon Hen I heard his cry. There many foes he fought, His cloven
shield, his broken sword, they to the water brought. His head so proud,
his face so fair, his limbs they laid to rest, And Rauros, golden
Rauros-falls, bore him upon its breast. ‘O Boromir! The Tower of Guard
shall ever northward gaze, To Rauros, golden Rauros-falls, until the end
of days.

title: Marchwarden
text:
MARCHWARDEN was a position given to highly skilled Elf rangers and
warriors who guarded the outer borders of their realms.


History

First Age

During the First Age, King Thingol of Doriath was served by
marchwardens, who guarded the borders of their forest. Two marchwardens,
Beleg Cúthalion and Mablung, fought in the Nírnaeth Arnoediad and
survived. Turin Turambar briefly served as one of the marchwardens,
and was often given tasks with his friend Beleg. At the end of the
First Age, Doriath was sacked by the Dwarves of Nogrod and later by the
remaining Sons of Fëanor, which resulted in the Second Kinslaying.
Doriath was ultimately defeated, and its marchwardens along with it.

Third Age

When the Fellowship of the Ring arrived in Lothlórien, its marchwardens,
led by Haldir and his brothers Rúmil and Orophin, encountered the group.
These wardens were described to wear grey-hooded cloaks. Haldir led the
Fellowship to Caras Galadhon, to meet Lady Galadriel and Lord
Celeborn, once a Prince of Doriath.


Named Marchwardens

-   Beleg Cúthalion, Chief Marchwarden of Doriath
-   Mablung, Marchwarden and Chief Captain of King Thingol
-   Turin Turambar
-   Haldir, Marchwarden of Lothlórien
-   Rúmil
-   Orophin

title: Fuithluin
text:
FUITHLUIN was an ogress who was in Tolkien's early concepts for the
Children of Ainur.


History

Fuithluin was an ogress who was in Tolkien's early concepts for the
Children of Ainur. She and Melkor (later Morgoth) gave birth to a son
named Kosomot (later Gothmog) who was a balrog.

title: Black Squirrels
text:
BLACK SQUIRRELS were a type of Squirrel native to Mirkwood.

They were black in color and no doubt lived in the trees of the dark
forest.


History

The Black Squirrels fur being black in color has not been fully
explained but it was likely due to the corrupting influence of Mirkwood
after Sauron built his realm in Dol Guldur after TA 1100. They were
encountered by Thorin and Company as they passed through Mirkwood.
During the day, Bilbo could see several of them running across the Path
and hiding behind the trunks of the trees. When the company's food began
to run short, the Dwarves figured they could shoot, cook, and eat them
wasting many arrows. When they did manage to get one of them and roast
it, they found the meat totally unpalatable and thus unfit for food just
as Beorn said most things would be save for nuts, and they shot no more
of them.

title: Banks Family
text:
BANKS was a common Hobbit family name, found in the Shire and Bree.


Known Family Members

-   Eglantine Banks: the mother of Peregrin Took
-   Willie Banks: a hobbit from Bree, who was killed in the Battle of
    Bywater who attacked Bree early in TA 3019.


Etymology

The name _banks_ is topographical, referring to “steep slopes or
hill-sides”.

title: Nen Lalaith
text:
NEN LALAITH was a stream in Dor-lómin.

It came from under the Amon Darthir and flowed past the house of Húrin
in southeastern Dor-lómin. According to _The Atlas of
Middle-earth_, it was just over twenty-five miles in length and
continued flowing northwestward towards the central part of
Dor-lómin.


History

Nen Lalaith was bridged during Fingon's rule as High King of the Ñoldor
in Hithlum. In Túrin's childhood, he could recall seeing the High King
for the first time, when he and his lords crossed it clad in glittering
silver and white. The stream was best known for being the name
(Lalaith) that the household of Húrin called the young daughter of Húrin
and sister of Túrin, Urwen or better known as 'Lalaith'.


Etymology

_Nen Lalaith_ was Sindarin for 'Water Laughter'.

title: Littleheart
text:
LITTLEHEART, whose birthname was ILFRIN, was an Elf of Tol Eressëa who
is mentioned only in early versions of the Middle-earth legendarium.


Biography

Ilfrin son of Bronweg was the “gong-warden” of a small host of Elves in
Tol Eressëa - the title was in referral to the gong Tombo, which he had
owned for much of his life. He served as a guide for a time to the Man
of Eriol while he was on Tol Eressëa. At the Cottage of Lost Play, he
once narrated the story of Tuor and the Fall and Exiles of Gondolin.

_Littleheart_ was what he was called by Lindo and Vairë, the keepers of
the Cottage.

It was once said by Gilfanon that this Elf was the only one still alive
who had seen the Necklace of the Dwarves. 


Etymology

Before _Ilfrin_ was the final version of his birthname, this character's
earlier names were INFINIOL,_' Elfriniol, Elfriniel_', ILFRITH, ELFRITH
, and (in the earliest tales) ILVERIN , which had replaced
ELWENILDO.

title: River Hobbits
text:
They are hobbits that live neither near or in a certain river and
Smeagol who turned into a river hobbit then got the name Gollum. River
hobbits are ugly creatures and are pretty much tiny monsters. They are
not your average hobbits.

title: Brockhouses Family
text:
BROCKHOUSE was a populous family of the Bree-hobbits. While some members
of the family lived in the Shire, Sapphira Brockhouse was the wife of
Uffo Boffin, and Bilbo Baggins greeted the Brockhouses among other
hobbit families in his famous farewell speech on September 22, TA 3001.



Notable Family Members

-   Sapphira Brockhouse

title: Oromet
text:
OROMET was a hill in the Andustar region of Númenor.

It was located very close to the shoreline in the utmost west of the
region near the haven of Andúnië.


History

Being high and as closest that a Man not on a ship could get to the
Undying Lands, Tar-Minastir, who longed for the lands west built a high
tower on the hill.

title: Strider (Pony)
text:
STRIDER was a pony acquired by Frodo Baggins in Minas Tirith that borne
him home.

Not much is known about the pony's early life.

Strider was rode by Frodo Baggins starting from Minas Tirith and rides
north to Rohan, then Isengard, Lórien, The Pass of Caradhras; and
finally arrives in Rivendell. After staying there for a fortnight,
Strider along with his master, Frodo and companions continue their
journey to Shire.

Two years later, the Horses carried his master, Frodo, westwards to the
Grey Havens on the coast of the Great Sea.


Etymology

The pony's name, “Strider” came from Aragorn's own nickname in the
northern lands.

title: Marshes of Nevrast
text:
The MARSHES OF NEVRAST were a wide area of marshland in the
land of Nevrast.

According to the Karen Wynn Fonstad's _The Atlas of Middle-earth_, the
marshes were approximately fifty miles in length and were situated
slightly southeast of the center of the land.

The marshes completely surrounded a lake called Linaewen.

title: Dimtilion
text:
DIMTILION was a Silvan Elf who served the Galadhrim Warriors that
defended Lothlórien's borders.


Biography

During the War of the Ring, Dimtilion was one hundreds of Silvan Elves
that followed Haldir to Helm's Deep and provide their support and aid to
the people of Rohan and their king from the terrible atrocities that
Saruman, who betrayed the White Council and became a servant of the Dark
Lord Sauron. Stationed at the Deeping Wall with all of his kin,
Dimtilion demonstrated his skills as an archer and killed a large number
of Uruk-hai that were climbing the wall. As he kept on fighting to
defend Rohan's people, Dimtilion was slain in the battle, but he would
be remembered of those that gave their lives in defending Rohan from the
armies of Isengard.

title: Hayward family
text:
The_' Hayward family_' was a Hobbit family of the Shire.


Notable Member

-   Hob Hayward


Etymology

In Old English, the world may be derived from the word “hay”, which
means “fence”, and “ward” which means “guard”.

title: Fish and Chips
text:
FISH AND CHIPS was a Hobbit meal. It consisted of fried Fish of any
variety and fried cut Potatoes.


History

While resting in Ithilien, Sam while arguing with Gollum about food
remarked that if he could he would cook him a good Fish and Chips,
courtesy of himself.

title: Browns Family
text:
BROWN is possibly a common Hobbit family name, found in Shire and Bree.



Notable Family Members

-   Lily Brown, wife of Tolman Cotton

title: Lords of Gondor
text:
LORDS OF GONDOR was a title of the Kingdom of Gondor.

This title referred to the nobility of Gondor, who ruled some remote
lands in Gondor.


History

During the Battle of the Pelennor Fields, they returned to the aid of
Minas Tirith. Unfortunately, most of the lords were killed in the
siege.

This title was possibly kept in the Fourth Age in the Reunited Kingdom.


Notable Lords

-   Imrahil: Prince of Dol Amroth
-   Duinhir: Lord of Blackroot Vale
-   Hirluin: Lord of Pinnath Gelin
-   Angbor: Lord of Lamedon
-   Golasgil: Lord of Anfalas
-   Unnamed Lord of Ringló Vale, he sent his son, Dervorin with 300 men,
    to aid Minas Tirith
-   Unnamed Lord of Cair Andros, he abandoned the city when Sauron's
    army sieged his land

title: Herugar
text:
Rudigar Bolger and Belba (Baggins) Bolger's son and only child. He was
the grandson of Mungo Baggins and Laura (Grubb) Baggins. Cousin of Bilbo
Baggins.

Born in by Shire Reckoning 1295 and died in 1390 aged 95. He married
Jessamine Boffin and had one son, Odovacar.

title: Bucklanders
text:
The BUCKLANDERS are the inhabitants that live in Buckland, located on
the eastern borders of the Shire.


History

The Bucklanders acknowledged the “Master of Buckland” as their leader.
The Brandybucks, descendants of Gorhendad Oldbuck who founded Buckland,
were considered the most important family of the Bucklanders. They all
had a strong Fallohidish strain in their blood, it is said, and this
made them more adventurous than many of their more conservative
neighbours in the Shire. They did not share the Shire-hobbits' fear of
water, for example, and the Bucklanders' boats where often seen on the
Brandywine River that bordered their land. On the eastern border of
Buckland lay the dangerous Old Forest, and the constant threat of the
dark trees made the Bucklanders somewhat hardier than typical hobbits.

title: New Mill
text:
The NEW MILL was the name for the mill that replaced the Old Mill during
the War of the Ring in the Shire.


History

After Lotho Sackville-Baggins was able to gain control of the Shire
through his dealings with Isengard and Saruman, he began a major
buying-up of property throughout the lands of the Shire. His goal was to
industrialize the Shire and make it more productive for his own gains.
One of the new projects was the expansion of the Sandyman's mill. Before
the war, the building was simply next to the river with only one known
water-wheel. Lotho had the old building knocked down by the Ruffians and
the building they built was a larger one covering the river. Inside the
New Mill there were many grinding wheels and other strange unknown
devices. Lotho's idea was to grind more and more grains faster and Ted
Sandyman approved of it and worked there for the men cleaning the
wheels.

title: Ancient Grey Mountains
text:
The ancient GREY MOUNTAINS were a series of mountains which continue the
line of the Blue Mountains as the western edge of Endor, but on the
southern half of the continent. Their position mirrors symmetrically
the Yellow Mountains in the east. This range was created when
the Valar thrust Middle-earth eastward to give more protection
to Valinor.

Since no maps of the entire world exist after the First Age, it is
unknown if this mountain line still existed later. In any case they do
not appear in the stories.

title: House of the Tree
text:
The HOUSE OF THE TREE was one of the noble Houses of the
Gondolindrim of Gondolin, under the leadership of Galdor. They wore
green, and carried iron-studded clubs and slings.


History

During the Fall of Gondolin, they were one of the two main kindreds that
first hurled themselves upon the Balrogs and Orcs upon the destruction
of the Gate of Gondolin. They guarded the western entrance to the Arch
of Inwë. Many escaped the slaughter with Tuor, and were scouts ahead of
the women and children, for they had “eyes like cats in the dark”, later
dwelling at the Mouths of Sirion. They are often referred to as
the _People_ or _Folk of Galdor_

title: Lemberin
text:
LEMBERIN, or LEMBIAN, was a name in early versions of
the legendarium for the Avarin languages, more particularly the Telerin.
It was spoken by the Lembi Elves, and was the most scattered and diverse
among the languages.

In the early writings, the Quendian (Elvish) languages were divided into
three: the Eldarin, Ilkorin, and Lemberin.

The Sindarin names _Thranduil, Legolas, Amroth, and Nimrodel_ were
considered as Lemberin. Celeborn's native tongue was originally
Lemberin, but was later changed to Telerin.

title: Herugar Bolger
text:
HERUGAR BOLGER was a Hobbit of the Shire.


Biography

Herugar was Rudigar Bolger and Belba (Baggins) Bolger's son and only
child. He was the grandson of Mungo Baggins and Laura (Grubb) Baggins.
Cousin of Bilbo Baggins.

Born in by Shire Reckoning 1295 and died in 1390 aged 95. He married
Jessamine Boffin and had one son, Odovacar Bolger.

title: Doors of Felagund
text:
The doors that guarded the entrance to Nargothrond, raised by its
builder Finrod Felagund. They were set in the face of a cliff above the
river Narog, and approached only by a narrow pathway across the cliff,
making Nargothrond secure from enemy attack.

After Felagund's death, Túrin came to dwell in Nargothrond, and he
persuaded King Orodreth to change this secretive policy, and to build a
great bridge before the Doors of Felagund, so that his armies could more
easily pass across the Narog. This was a dire error, because it
gave Morgoth's forces a means to approach the Doors. After the Battle of
Tumhalad, Glaurung the Dragon came against the Doors of Felagund and
destroyed them, allowing the Orcs to sack the once-mighty citadel.

title: Rune
text:
The RUNIC ALPHABET was a system of writing based on angular shapes that
could easily be carved into wood or stone. It originated and was used
mainly in Northern Europe, by the Anglo-Saxons and the Norse tribes. One
theory says that Runes evolved from Etruscan writing, however other
quasi-runic scripts in other parts of the world (Rovásírás andOrkhon
Script) also exist.


Tolkien and Runes

J.R.R. Tolkien decided that his peoples of Arda would also use a similar
script, and “Runes” are mentioned in his narratives.

In _The Hobbit_, Tolkien used Old English runes, or Futharc, to display
the writing of the Dwarves on the Thrór's Map; his Dwarves however were
based mainly on Norse culture and their language is influenced of
Semitic languages. The texts of course are modern English, and
display the use of Westron of the Third Age.

The foreword of _The Hobbit_ (50th anniversary edition and later)
explains the usage of the Old English runes and help the reader read the
Map (although the translations are also revealed in the end of Chapter
3, _A Short Rest_)

Eventually Tolkien elaborated on a totally original runic writing system
while writing _The Lord of the Rings_. Although most of the letters
between historical runes and Tolkien's “cirth” are identical, they do
not share the same values, since the Cirth follow the phonetic
principles of the Tengwar.

In the history of Arda, a runic script called Cirth was invented
by Daeron of Doriath to represent Sindarin words. Runes came to be used
widely by races other than the Elves, and especially by the Dwarves.

title: Forhend
text:
'''Forhend '''was a Man of Brethil, and a guard of the Crossings of
Teiglin, in the First Age.


Biography

Forhend was one of the guards under the command of Manthor who came
across weary Húrin in Haudh-en-Elleth, immediately after the events
recounted in _The Children of Húrin._ When Manthor, who recognized
Húrin, left towards Obel Halad (the Hall of the Haladin) to assist Húrin
in his errand, he took only him and Forhend along. The others of the
Guard, such as Sagroth and Avranc, were to stay behind.

It is possible that Forhend was of some familial relation to Forweg, one
of the outlaws encountered earlier by Túrin Turambar in lands near to
Brethil.

title: House of the Hammer of Wrath
text:
The HOUSE OF THE HAMMER OF WRATH was one of
the kindred of Gondolin whose lord was Rog.

They were great smiths and craftsmen, and revered Aulë. In battle they
carried great maces like hammers, and heavy shields, for they had strong
arms. The device of this people was the Stricken Anvil and a hammer that
smites sparks about it; this was set upon their shields, for red gold
and black iron was their delight. They had a great hatred for Morgoth
and the Balrogs, and during the Fall of Gondolin they slew a number of
the fell beasts, being the first of Elves and Men alike to slay a
balrog. All of them perished in that battle, when a large force of
Balrogs, Orcs and Fire-drakes was unleashed upon them.it:Casata del
Martello dell'Ira

title: Cirith Thoronath
text:
CIRITH THORONATH was a pass in the Echoriath northwest of Gondolin.


History

Cirith Thoronath was the place through which the refugees from the Fall
of Gondolin made their escape after passing through Idril's Secret Way.
It was here that they were set upon by a Balrog, who was challenged by
Glorfindel, leading to a fierce battle between the two. After ruining
its helmet and piercing its belly, Glorfindel was dragged by the demon
over a nearby cliff, with both falling to their deaths. 


Etymology

_Cirith Thoronath_ was Sindarin for 'cleft of the eagles'.

title: Avranc
text:
AVRANC was a Man of Brethil during the First Age, son of Dorlas.


Biography

Avranc was once a man under Manthor's authority, who was a lord of the
Haladin. When Manthor's company came across Húrin Thalion near
Haudh-en-Elleth, after the death of Morwen, Avranc broke Manthor's
command by running ahead to the house of Hardang the Chieftan, without
leave, to tell Hardang of Manthor's bringing Húrin to him.

Hardang later made Avranc a Captain of Brethil during the time of
Húrin's imprisonment there. When a battle broke out after the 301st
Folkmoot of Judgment, at which Húrin was put to trial for his
wrongdoings against Hardang, Manthor and Avranc were enemies. In the
end, Avranc wounded Manthor with an arrow, and managed to escape. After
Húrin's departure from Brethil, Manthor died.


Etymology

Rejected names

''Farang ''and ''Faranc ''were two names Tolkien rejected for this
character.

title: Obel Halad
text:
OBEL HALAD was the fortified place in Brethil in which stood the Hall of
the Halad (Hall of the Chieftains of Brethil).


History

It was to Obel Halad that Manthor, with Forhend and Húrin, came from
Haudh-en-Elleth to assist Húrin on his “errand” and bring him to
Chieftan Hardang.

title: The High Road
text:
History

A high road ran between Ost-in-Edhil and Khazad-dûm, built during the
Second Age by the Elves of Eregion and The Dwarves of Khazad-dûm, it
enabled an unprecedented friendship between the two peoples and would
last as long as their realms did. Eregion's jewel smiths, under
Celebrimbor, achieved the highest levels of craftsmanship since Fëanor,
and the Dwarves of Durin III's work in Mithril enamored all who beheld
them as trade between the two realms grew. It would be well into The
Fourth Age until another friendship between Elf and Dwarf would come
close to this alliance.


Biography

_“Eregion was nigh to the great mansions of the Dwarves that were named
Khazad-dûm, but by the Elves Hadhodrond, and afterwards Moria. From
Ost-in-Edhil, the city of the Elves, the highroad ran to the west gate
of Khazad-dûm, for a friendship arose between Dwarves and Elves, such as
has never elsewhere been, to the enrichment of both those peoples. In
Eregion the craftsmen of the Gwaith-i-Mírdain, the People of the
Jewel-smiths, surpassed in cunning all that have ever wrought” _

_“...they saw below them a deep and narrow channel. It was empty and
silent ... but on the near side there was a path, much broken and
decayed, that wound its way among the ruined walls and paving-stones of
an ancient highroad.” _

_“There are the Walls of Moria,' said Gandalf, pointing across the
water. 'And there the Gate stood once upon a time, the Elven Door at the
end of the road from Hollin by which we have come.” _

_“Here the Elven-way from Hollin ended. Holly was the token of the
people of that land, and they planted it here to mark the end of their
domain; for the West-door was made chiefly for their use in their
traffic with the Lords of Moria.” _


Named references

title: Evranin
text:
EVRANIN was an Elf of the First Age, and a nurse of Elwing's who, in an
early version of the tale of the Necklace of the Dwarves, helped steal
the Necklace away from the reach of Feanor's sons, alongside one named
Gereth.

title: The Fall of Erebor
text:
THE FALL OF EREBOR was a catastrophic event in the Third Age. In summer,
an enormous Fire-drake named Smaug descended on the mountain and
destroyed Dale and the Kingdom of the Dwarves of the Lonely Mountain.

title: Gereth
text:
GERETH was one who aided the flight of Evranin from Artanor (the place
which would become Doriath), during the years following the battles
between Elves and the Nauglath. They two bore the Necklace of the
Dwarves away from the sons of Feanor.

Gereth and Evranin are not mentioned in the final story of the Necklace
of the Dwarves in _The Silmarillion._

title: Eltas
text:
ELTAS was an inhabitant of Tol Eressëa at some time during the First
Age.


Biography

At the Cottage of Lost Play, Eltas once told to others the earliest
known tale of Turambar and the Faolókë. Following that, he traveled to
Tavrobel, during which time the Fall of Gondolin was then retold by
Littleheart (Ilfiniol).

Eltas' family is unknown.

title: House of the Heavenly Arch
text:
The HOUSE OF THE HEAVENLY ARCH was one of the twelve houses of the
Gondolindrim in the First Age. Their captain was Egalmoth. 

The Elves of this house wore vestiture of many vivid colors, since _The
Heavenly Arch_ referred to the rainbow. Along with those of the House of
the Swallow, these Elves were the finest archers in Gondolin, and some
of the greatest swordsmen. Each of their weapons was set with bright
jewels, and their shields were blue, bearing in the middle seven
precious minerals of color.

During Gondolin's fall, bowmen of the Heavenly Arch fired many volleys
of arrows upon enemy orcs at the city's northern walls. As the odds of
the onslaught turned slowly against the Gondolindrim, these defenders
retreated to the Square of the Palace, along with others, where Tuor
gathered them. By the end of the battle, few warriors of the House of
the Heavenly Arch had escaped and lived on.
